creator: sfaber@alcatel-lucent.com
text:
Some of the documentation implies that the WebServices has
Cookie support always enabled.  If this is the case, then 
a HTTP response with a Set-Cookie in the header should have the
JSESSIONID returned in a Cookie parameter in the  HTTP header of
the following requests.  This does not happen.  Adding a Cookie manager 
does not help.  Other forum reports indicate others had the problem
and solved it by a regex scrip to extract appropriate cookie parameters
from the http headers.  This report is to request cookie support be fixed.

creator: left@ultrasis.com
text:
I am having the same problem. I am trying to use jmeter 2.3 to test a site 
which uses a form to login into a site.  However adding a cookie manager 
doesn't seem to allow jmeter to keep state, the next page doesn't seem to be 
aware of the session cookie.

I have tried version 2.2 and it seems fine, importing a testing plan from 
version 2.2 into 2.3 seems like a work around.

(In reply to comment #1)
> I am having the same problem. I am trying to use jmeter 2.3 to test a site 
> which uses a form to login into a site.  However adding a cookie manager 
> doesn't seem to allow jmeter to keep state, the next page doesn't seem to be 
> aware of the session cookie.

Are you using WebServices here? It uses its own transport.

> I have tried version 2.2 and it seems fine, importing a testing plan from 
> version 2.2 into 2.3 seems like a work around.

Have you tried that? I doubt very much that would work.
creator: sebb@apache.org
left@ultrasis.com
text:
Thank you for the reply.

My mistake, my testing plans were slightly diffrent for the two versions which 
explains the diffrent results, what i have found is a odd struts feature which 
gave odd results (for the intrested - basically you need to call the form 
before you call the form action).  

Sorry for the mistake, I was too hasty!

(In reply to comment #2)
> (In reply to comment #1)
> > I am having the same problem. I am trying to use jmeter 2.3 to test a site 
> > which uses a form to login into a site.  However adding a cookie manager 
> > doesn't seem to allow jmeter to keep state, the next page doesn't seem to 
be 
> > aware of the session cookie.
> Are you using WebServices here? It uses its own transport.
> > I have tried version 2.2 and it seems fine, importing a testing plan from 
> > version 2.2 into 2.3 seems like a work around.
> Have you tried that? I doubt very much that would work.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text: Webservices uses its own transport and cookie handling is not changeable, as far as I can tell
